Difficult conversations.Super_Section:
The fear of difficult conversations is keeping our society stuck in one place.

We avoid talking about a living will, changes in our climate, and other sensitive topics because we consider them difficult subjects. However, not all conversations are difficult, and not all conversations should be viewed as such. What makes a difficult conversation?

A difficult conversation is caused by the desire to change not one, but two things. If we want to say one thing only, we usually don’t consider it a difficult conversation because it’s clear what we want and should do. But when we ask for two things, we feel like we’re asking for too much and hesitate to even discuss it. 

But when other factors are added to the equation, the conversation is not difficult. In fact, it’s often required to help the group, the company, or the entity achieve their common goal.

‍

Authority

Exercising your authority and enforcing rules is not a difficult conversation. You shouldn’t care about what the other party is thinking while you’re exercising your authority, because you have the right and responsibility to do so. If you don’t have it or don’t believe in your authority, it’s then when the conversation becomes difficult. You need to have confidence in your authority and not care what the other person thinks. 

‍

Enrollment

When someone is enrolled in the group and working towards the same goal, there are no difficult conversations. This is because everyone is focused on the same thing and working towards the same goal, so it’s easier to share ideas, resources, and solve problems.

That’s why the best way to move past a difficult conversation is to spend time on enrollment. When someone is an active member of a company, a group, or a community, it’s easier for them to accept criticism and work towards the same goal.

‍

Direct conversation

Once you’ve spent all mutual resources and ways to move forward, it’s best to avoid making a difficult conversation by being direct. Don’t be afraid to say no and be direct about it. If everyone is enrolled in the group, they will want the unit to move forward and will accept your decision more easily. 

‍

Respectful ultimatum

When you offer a respectful ultimatum to any of the people, it’s not a difficult conversation. Every member has enrolled and agreed on the working standards, so asking them to respect them is not a difficult conversation. If someone is being disrespectful and crossing the lines you and the group have set, set a respectful ultimatum. If they don’t respect it, ask them nicely to do it, or else they will be excluded from the group. 

This is not a difficult conversation. You’re simply asking to work together towards the same goal by maintaining a good working environment. 

‍

Contribution

Being enrolled in a journey with the group means investing and expecting others to invest their time and resources. It’s a mutual agreement to work towards the same goal as a group, and put the common interest before the personal one.

Andrew Wilkinson on building the berkshi.Super_Section:
The road not taken

Andrew made his way from founding a design agency in Canada to creating a multi-million dollar company like Tiny. It all began with the tech news site Andrew launched in high school, through which he claims he received his “MBA-like training”. At 16, he had the opportunity to interview Steve Jobs, and he traveled across the world. After graduating, he moved to Silicon Valley and founded the freelancing agency, Metalab. 

Soon he became the go-to guy for designing web apps, mobile apps, and websites for major corporations like Apple, Google, Walmart, and Facebook. But running an agency was a lot of work, as he always needed to win new clients, so to escape this, Andrew started looking for SAS and recurring revenue. Inspired by the work David and Jason were doing with Basecamp, he started multiple SAS companies that initially built softwares. He kept diversifying and making new companies, and by 2013, he was CEO of more than five big businesses. Overwhelmed with this life, he started selling some of his companies to generate capital for investment. Learning from Warren Buffett’s Berkshire model, he visualised a similar business model for tech, and founded Tiny. 


I wanna acquire companies like New Zealand

Andrew says that he prefers to acquire companies that are like New Zealand - in the middle of nowhere, quietly successful, profitable, not where other investors are looking, and away from nuclear war. He prefers to go for a 10-100 million opportunity rather than a 10 billion one with more risk. Their investments are not always venture capitals; most of them are in bootstrap businesses where founders are paid for a price based on where the company is at that point, what earnings are expected, and what risk it has in the future. Portfolio construction is not a concern at Tiny, as evaluation is done on a deal by deal basis, after judging if the investment will last the test of time. Diversifying is done very cautiously.

“I think like with a lot of founders I’m very urgent. I love doing things quickly. I love ideas, I love strategy. What I don’t really like is implementation and follow-through and managing people.” -Andrew Wilkinson

The pandemic has definitely affected revenue models. At Tiny, they still don’t know what the 2nd and 3rd order effects will be, but since all of their companies work remotely, they’ve been able to pivot easily. Some businesses have definitely been affected more, but in those cases, the strategy is to scale down cost and keep an eye on it. Andrew explains that they only buy profitable businesses. The key is sustainability, and growth is only a second priority. He doesn’t believe that it is necessary to sacrifice your profits to be able to show growth.


Notes on board leadership

When you’re a board member, remember you’re not the CEO’s friend. You are there to ask probing questions and rub their nose in the consequences of what could go wrong. Even if you own the entire company, you can’t dictate what they do. You’re ultimately deciding, ‘Is this the right person to run this business, or not?’ It is useful to think about incentives to align your CEOs, and sometimes CEOs need to make mistakes to learn from them. Even if it may sound like a bad idea, Andrew only intervenes if a bad decision is at a “sink the company '' level. Otherwise he uses the “disagree but commit” strategy. You must definitely double down on your strengths but also make sure you know enough about your weaknesses so you can delegate those parts to people who are good at those aspects. While hiring, Andrew always looks for his candidates’ outcomes. Have they done this before? How well did they do it? In his experience, if you hire for potential it always fails. 

“I’ve realised that, ultimately, the main things that matter are being able to be part of a community and having activities you can engage in, having friends, and having a wonderful family and grandchildren.” - Andrew Wilkinson

Arianna Huffington - WHAT GREAT FOUNDERS.Super_Section:
The problem with current work culture

Many entrepreneurs wrongly believe that insufficient sleep does not affect their performance. The current work culture glorifies pulling all-nighters and never stopping the grind. However, constant self-sacrifice is unsustainable. 

Recharging involves more than getting sufficient sleep. Employees and founders also need to lower their stress levels. 

“75% of healthcare causes and healthcare problems are stress-related and preventable.” – Arianna Huffington

There is a Yin and Yang relationship between building one’s startup and refueling.

“The idea is to keep them balanced, not to let one eclipse the other.” – Reid Hoffman 

Inspired by her own experience and the prevailing mentality of entrepreneurial culture, Arianna Huffington authored “Thrive” to bring attention to this toxic culture. 

Jack Ma, founder of Alibaba, suggested to Huffington that she start a company around the valuable insights in her book. Those words planted the seed that culminated in 2016 with Huffington launching “Thrive Global” with the aim of preventing burnout while maximizing efficiency through sleep and rejuvenation.


The science behind productivity and sleep

Dr. Matt Walker says it has been scientifically proven that insufficient sleep can hinder employees’ productivity and problem-solving capabilities. It also increases the likelihood they will be dishonest or unethical in the workplace. 

And these negative impacts affect CEOs’ behavior too.

“The more or less sleep a business leader has had for one night to the next, the more or less charismatic and inspiring the employees will rate that business leader from one day to the next.” – Dr. Matt Walker

Chris Yeh wrote an essay titled “Napping My Way To Success In Silicon Valley” wherein he recounts how a 20-minute nap per day has increased his productivity and greatly contributed to his success over the last decade. 

Scientific research has proven that tiredness impacts our brain’s frontal lobes and impairs our cognitive abilities. 

“I can trace all of my hiring mistakes to being tired.” – Arianna Huffington

Rejuvenation sessions do not need to be very lengthy. 

“Neuroscience tells us it takes under 60 seconds to course correct from stress.” – Arianna Huffington

This issue extends beyond mental health, it is also about business. 

“A founder who has pushed themselves too far and is running on empty becomes a liability to themselves, their employees, and their investors.” - Reid Hoffman


Implementing a sustainable work culture in your own life and company

Similar to how children also require a bedtime routine, adults also need a transition to sleep, so establish a bedtime ritual. Whether you are an employee or entrepreneur, declare an end to your work day at a set time. Be willing to disconnect from work; switch off your electronics and keep them out of sight. 

When instilling a culture of rejuvenation in your company, always remember that different people have different capacities, priorities, and ways of recharging. 

Naturally, there will be occasions when employees will have to exert themselves or pull all-nighters to meet deadlines. That is not the issue.

“People never have a problem with what they do occasionally. It’s what’s expected of [them] every day that’s the problem.” – Arianna Huffington

Implementing “entry interviews” with employees will allow you to learn about their priorities and set up a workspace for them that is in harmony with those priorities.

Paradoxically, technology can either get in the way of rejuvenation or be used to create/reinforce a healthy work culture.

Small course corrections in the company culture can have a huge impact on wellness. 

“The impact of a single angry customer call can cascade through an employee’s day, taking down productivity, team morale, and… employee retention.” – Reid Hoffman

Any company can implement a sustainable work culture.

“These are small changes that can have a huge impact. That’s what is so wonderful.” – Arianna Huffington

Ask Daily Stoic: Ryan and Robert Greene.Super_Section:
Lessons from Pericles relevant to COVID-19

Pericles was an influential Greek army general and public speaker. He loved rationality and made decisions based on what would benefit the majority, not himself. Unfortunately, the trend among most political leaders today is to focus on benefiting themselves.

Like Pericles, leaders should think long-term, develop effective plans for potential crises, and implement them during critical times. Rather than fall into the trap of thinking that favourable circumstances will last indefinitely, leaders must recognize that disasters are inevitable and unpredictable. So they need to plan ahead and successfully persuade the public to stick to the plan.

Regardless of our political views, we need to do everything within our power to keep the people around us safe. Though it is fair to say that scientists are still learning about the SARS-CoV-2 virus, they still know more than we do. So we must follow their lead if we want to succeed.

“The only way out of this [pandemic] is by following the science.” - Robert Greene


The root of unproductive political discussions

Richard Sennett’s book, The Fall of the Public Man, highlights how people’s ego and narcissism are tied up in their politics. For this reason, many people (regardless of political orientation) tend to become personally offended whenever anyone expresses doubt or hostility towards a leader or policy that they support.

“It’s not a Left or Right problem, it’s a cultural problem.” - Robert Greene

It is easy to attach one’s own self-worth to how the group is valued. A person may reason, “If you label the person that I voted for as incompetent or immoral, then it’s as though you’re labelling me as incompetent or immoral.” But we must avoid such toxic thinking. As challenging as it may be to do so, we need to separate our self-worth from our politics. 

Discussions of different viewpoints should be based on rationality, inner security, and open-mindedness, not emotion. When a person attacks a political view, don’t interpret it as an attack on you as a person. Analyze the value of each idea for yourself; don’t simply rely on what others think. Be open to changing your point of view when presented with logical ideas.

“You have to be more interested in ideas than in your ego.” - Robert Greene


Managing Our Emotions and Our Lives

More often than not, we tend to allow our emotions to lead us. So challenge yourself to reflect on and detach from your emotions.

“The only way to be rational in this world is to realize that you are mostly irrational.” - Robert Greene

Only if we take the time to be rational first, can we then leverage our emotions. For example, rather than let your anger blind you, analyze what caused it and whether or not it is a justified response. Once you have done so, you can channel that negative emotion into productive results and strategic decisions.

The time that you are alive is the only true possession you have. You can choose to either give it away to other people or you can take ownership of it. Look for ways to “own” obstacles by using them as opportunities to discover more about yourself, grow, and be creative.

During the lockdown, rather than look for ways to merely distract yourself, take ownership of these stressful circumstances by gaining knowledge and developing new skills. Robert finds that reading books is a great way to “explore” the world and other people’s minds even when you’re stuck at home.

Ask Daily Stoic: Ryan Talks Freedom and.Super_Section:
We need to re-establish character in the American system

David calls John Adams and Thomas Jefferson the frenemies of the Founding. As the declaration of independence says: We are endowed by our creator with certain unalienable rights. We have a responsibility to exercise our rights in a virtuous manner, and should not take these rights and abuse them. 

Rights-based liberalism is the foundation of the US constitution, but the US government is not effective at enforcing virtue.

Heraclitus argued that character is fate. With the current situation, David says we are relearning the power of character. 

‍

“Nothing is foolproof against human corruption”

There are more and more signs of distrust towards the system, and if political institutions cannot be trusted, the system will break. David argues that there is a need for a reboot of “character”. When the other party cheats, it’s difficult to stick with your integrity. 

Same goes for the media, who treat scandals differently from one person to the next. This makes it impossible to establish a standard, though it’s necessary to establish fair and even standards that apply to all.

‍

Lessons from Iraq and ancient Consantinople

Islamic denominations Sunni and Shia could not identify the difference in government style whether the Sunni or Shia ruled, but they remember exactly when one party attacked the other. It seems like we, too, now only remember attacks.

Chariot racing became a form of politics in Constantinople, when the empire was just about to fall. This is an example of turning politics into sports. 

‍

The Misuse of Twitter in politics

Today’s chariot racing revolves around social media, and everyone in politics and the media are obsessively using Twitter, creating a toxic environment that sadly determines national mood and policy.

“Everyone is always airing their grievances….There is an enormous amount of misery out there.” - David French 

Kindness is seen as a weakness on Twitter. You are being forced to be angry, and many people assume that the opposite end of the political spectrum has no knowledge or wisdom to offer. We need to be open to critique.

‍

“David Frenchism” and the Drag Queen Story Hour

David had to defend himself and the American Founding after taking a positive stance towards Drag Queen Story Hour, a movement in Sacramento, California where drag queens read to children. Following this, people tried to discredit the movement of David French by discrediting the creator himself. 

‍

Are we doing a bad job telling the story of American history?  

“The entire Bill of Rights is a firewall against majoritarian tyranny”. -David French 

The focus lies mostly on unimportant issues like Drag Queen Story Hour, and only sometimes is it used to stop civil wars. Americans have failed to fulfill the ideas of the founding fathers, and again and again the Bill of Rights has been violated, from slavery to post-WW2 social segregation.

The founders set up a system motivated by a political ideology that had irreconcilable tensions with existing oppressive structures. This resulted in the constant push for liberty, even though it took a while. There are always two sides to any battle, and the outcome depends on which side is being portrayed as heroes. 

‍

What should people working in the federal government do now? 

There is a lot of tension in the federal government at the moment. People need to watch out not to become instruments of dishonesty. There is a dire need for good people in the government, however if a good person is serving a broken system, they may get broken too. Politicians feel that they are indispensable, and are unwilling to let go of their power. They should recognize the time when their ego led them to stop serving their country, and resign.

Bitcoin & Time - Misir Mahmudov on Tales.Super_Section:
This Book Will Save You Time. Why did you write this new book?

Misir has faced great difficulty communicating the facts about bitcoin,which is a sad phenomenon as everybody could profit from bitcoin. Most people don’t understand how money works, so we cannot expect them to understand how bitcoin works. 

Bitcoin has led to a collection of memes, which are easy to understand and used to communicate the idea of bitcoin. At the moment, there is a meme war going on. 



If you want someone to care about bitcoin, they need to see what is in it for them. Finding an empathy touchpoint is important. The Food Inc. documentary, for example, created empathy to get its point across. 

It’s important to explain basic concepts of scarcity. Time is your only really scarce resource, and on average we have 600,000 hours to live. Everyday you exchange your time for pieces of paper that are created out of thin air. Why would you exchange your finite time for something infinite?

Misir’s book was inspired by the movie In Time, which explains the concept of “time is money”. In the movie, the rich have thousands of years to live whereas the poor only have days, sometimes hours. 

‍

Why should you read the book? 

It explains in a very simplistic way how bitcoin saves you time. 

Money should be limited in supply, but it’s not. The result is that we spend more time working than we should. With an inflation rate of 5% per year, it means that after five years your money is worth 50% less. Savings are therefore not reliable.


Shrinkflation: the insidious method to hide the problems of capitalism 

The first 7-8 chapters of the book do not mention bitcoin. They explain scarcity, attention economy and other principles that are necessary to understand before people can really appreciate bitcoin.

Shrinkflation: the practice of reducing the size of a product while maintaining its sticker price, thus hiding the effects of inflation. For example, a Snickers bar in 2014 weighed 232 grams and cost £0.74. In 2018, it has shrunk to 167 grams and costs £1.26 = 28% smaller and 71% more expensive. The consumer price index is adjusted to “consumer habits,” which hides the decrease in the quality of food that is purchased. 

Who is the book for? 

The main audience are the “nocoiners”, or people who have heard about bitcoin but haven’t understood the concept. “I am really anticipating the reaction from people who know nothing about Bitcoin… they are the real audience to prove how successful this book is.” Misir calls the book a “Bitcoin primer disguised as a self-help book.”


The central banking situation looks grim

Crypto voices released their monetary report for 2020, showing how bad the economic situation is actually getting. Also, Max Hildebrand warned about hyperinflation in May 2020. 

“We have more and more dollars chasing less and less goods being produced.”- Marty Bent 

Bitcoin may be succeeding because the world's system is not working. “Bitcoin fixes literally everything.”- Misir Mahmudov

Pumping more money into the system is just procrastinating the inevitable collapse of the system.


Sold on a non-profit basis

The book’s revenue is donated to bitcoin developers. Misir aims to spread the message, and will help develop the bitcoin system.

Amazon takes care of all the publishing, shipping and handling for a 40% cut. Misir urges people to consider this option to quickly publish a book.

There is a potential technological solution in a world where you are forced to work non stop, where you have to run like a hamster in a wheel, where you have to chase the cart like a donkey. There is a potential to break free. There is a way to store heart and wealth in something that is finite in something that is not being constantly devalued through deflation. Unlike any other currency, bitcoin is designed to value your time…

Introduction to FringeSport 

Peter Keller’s passion for fitness moved him to start FringeSport in 2010, with the aim to “help people improve their lives through strength.” FringeSport is a direct-to-consumer company that sells gym equipment to customers who want to establish their own garage gyms, or set up a community gym. 


Thinking like a “3rd-century trader”

Rather than go down the more common path of starting a venture-backed direct-to-consumer (or D2C) company, Peter established FringeSport as a bootstrap direct-to-consumer company. 

This means that the only capital he raised to start FringeSport was his own money, with no outside investors at all. While modern business philosophy emphasizes scaling and customer acquisition first, and profits second, Peter flipped the script and approached it like a “3rd-century trader”. This meant using only (1) his limited capital and (2) his skills as an entrepreneur to make a profit with every sale while creating value for customers.

Without external funding, Peter has the freedom and control to steer the company wherever he believes would be best for it. 

“I haven’t had to sacrifice what I believed was in the best interest of our customers.” - Peter Keller

At the same time, Peter reminds listeners that choosing this path means it would take a while for a business to reach a sizable scale, but he personally believes it will be worthwhile.

“You can ultimately be in charge of your destiny if you’re willing to grow a little slower.” - Peter Keller


Customer acquisition without advertisements

Peter referenced an eye-opening article titled “Start-Up Drugs”, wherein Andy Dunn likens advertisements to drugs for start-ups because they make entrepreneurs feel good (by providing revenue) -- but at a high cost. 

Many entrepreneurs are anxious that if they stop spending so much money on advertisements, their revenue will disappear. But Peter has found an alternative way to acquire customers. FringeSport employs a content-focused marketing strategy. In other words, FringeSport generates free, helpful, and valuable content to help their customers. 

Whether it is through blog posts, participating in offsite web forums, or creating detailed and informative product pages, FringeSport generates free content that answers customers’ questions and helps them make wise consumer decisions, even if that means they will buy from elsewhere. 

This strategy is not about trying to get customers to buy FringeSport’s products, but rather to establish a connection with them. He views this strategy as a way to give back to his customers, which is preferable to giving money to Facebook or Google for ads. 


A clear vision and mission

Peter is passionate about “helping people improve their lives through strength.” It is this conviction that drives him to provide his customers with quality products and practical advice. Despite the bootstrap technique, he still has big dreams for FringeSport. He aims to build it an international reputation as the best place for community and information regarding the garage and community gym movements. 

Because he has such a deep understanding of his customers and what they’re trying to achieve, Peter has been able to make company decisions with their best interests at heart. This technique is not new by any means. Companies like Patagonia also focused on their customers, and they are still around today.

“I would be overjoyed to pilot Fringe[Sport] into the future more or less forever.” - Peter Keller

Clone or Create? Aaron Tan on The Ventur.Super_Section:
Clone or create?

Aaron Tan started his first company when he was 13, and had already sold two companies by the time he turned 20. However, his entrepreneurial career got sidetracked when he accepted a government scholarship to pursue computer science education in the United States.

When he returned to Singapore, he worked at venture capital firm Singtel. After having fulfilled his obligations, he decided to get back to starting companies again, and having dealt with automotive companies while in venture capital, he focused on the automotive business because of its great potential. He was inspired to start his company when he looked back on his years in the US, where he had bought several cars using services like Carfax and Kelley Blue Book, which provide information about a car’s condition, history, and value. These kinds of services did not exist in Southeast Asia.

“So I don’t think that there is a need to be super innovative and come up with something that is entirely unique. I think there are gaps in the market, but not all gaps are equally translatable.” - Aaron Tan

What this teaches us is that building a new business isn’t always about creating a new model. Sometimes, understanding the market you’re after and the viable opportunities is what’s important.


It’s all about priorities!

Tan says his business focus shifts every few months. Right now, during the COVID-19 outbreak, he is mainly focused on managing cash and hiring more engineers that can work from home.

“The two things we’re investing in are growth and making sure that the company stays afloat for a long, long time.”

The engineers are busy because they are working on the business’s platform, so that Carro can be prepared for whatever other challenges the future may bring.


Maintaining an open culture

With Carro’s operations split across different countries - and different languages -, Tan believes in a “divide and conquer” approach. The company is divided into different teams, which operate on their own under guidelines set up by the company. 

Over time, Carro has worked on and improved their process of company-wide communication, getting feedback from staff members, and being transparent to employees about what was happening in other parts of the company.

On that note, Tan describes Carro’s culture with one word: open.

“I don’t think we have an internal issue where people don’t speak up, so for me it’s about making sure people give useful feedback. Has it been useful? I think so.”

When asked what kind of people he wants working for his company, Tan said he looks for individuals who are more focused on governance than on being mavericks.

‍
Sprinting and going all in

After finishing his conversation with Tan, Venture host Andrew Roth spoke with fellow McKinsey associate Tomas Laboutka, another experienced entrepreneur, about the steps Tan took to start his company: evaluating what the key segments were for the automotive market, what services were missing and whether or not it could work in Tan’s region, and whether or not there was a strong player already in the market there.

“After getting all the answers, which drove him toward Carro, he just started sprinting, with focus, and went all in.” - Tomas Laboutka

Laboutka and Roth also remarked how Carro is moving forward with investing, even during a global pandemic when economic activity is otherwise at a standstill. On the one hand, you make sure your financial “burn” is kept as low as possible, but on the other hand, you move forward and make bold moves with investing in talent and building up a culture that can ensure your company lasts for years to come.

“This was something that really struck me as he spoke about the 400 people whom he ultimately asks, not anonymously, what it is that he should be focusing on, and where they should go. So being open is something that really stood out.”

COVID-19 Q&A with Rhonda Patrick, Ph.D.Super_Section:
Disclaimer: The information discussed by Dr. Rhonda Patrick is not meant to diagnose or treat any disease. 

When studying COVID-19, do not make the common mistake of drawing broad conclusions from an isolated fact because this will lead to wrong solutions.

‍
Children and COVID-19

A March 2020 study found that children of all ages (regardless of gender) are susceptible to COVID-19. However, children at higher risk include:

  • Infants and preschoolers
  • Immunocompromised children
  • Children with other pulmonary health problems

Manifestations of COVID-19 symptoms in children have generally been milder compared to the symptoms in adults. Furthermore, COVID-19 related deaths among children have been extremely rare. 

“Children’s immune systems are still developing and may respond to pathogens very differently from adults.” - Dr. Rhonda Patrick

Studies have found no evidence of mother-child transmission of COVID-19 either through pregnancy or through breastfeeding. Hence, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that nursing mothers who tested positive for the virus wash their hands before touching their infants and wear face masks while breastfeeding.


Hydroxychloroquine and COVID-19

Hydroxychloroquine is an inexpensive generic drug known for treating rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. It should not be taken at home without a physician’s guidance because its side effects include:

  • Gastrointestinal effects (vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, etc.)
  • Retinopathy

Only limited (and conflicted) data is available regarding its effectiveness in treating COVID-19. 

“Larger randomized control trials are needed to confirm whether or not hydroxychloroquine is an effective treatment for COVID-19.” - Dr. Rhonda Patrick


Quercetin and COVID-19

Quercetin is a flavonoid found in plants and is an FDA-approved drug ingredient. While it was proven effective in blocking the original virus that caused the initial outbreak (SARS-CoV-1), it has not been clinically tested for the current version of the virus (SARS-CoV-2). 

Canada and China are collaborating on a clinical trial using it; the results are expected to come out in four months. 


Blood types and COVID-19

There is “very little evidence” that Type A blood groups are at higher risk of contracting COVID-19 compared to non-Type A groups. It is possible that Type O blood groups may have a lower risk of infection due to the types of antibodies their blood produces. Most of this limited evidence is connected to SARS-CoV-1, not the current version of the virus.


Vitamin D and COVID-19

While it is well-established that Vitamin D plays an important role in immune defense in general and that it can be protective against respiratory tract infections, its effect on COVID-19 is still unclear.

“Whether Vitamin D really does play a crucial role in COVID-19 defense — only time will tell.” - Dr. Rhonda Patrick


Saunas and COVID-19

There is no official data to suggest that saunas, hot baths, steam showers, etc. could affect COVID-19 at all. However, there is a 2017 study that examines the effects of sauna use on pneumonia (a symptom of severe COVID-19 illness).

‍

Intravenous Vitamin C and COVID-19

There is evidence regarding Vitamin C’s positive impact for patients suffering from Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome and Sepsis. But there is no published data regarding the effects on treating COVID-19 specifically. 

There is only anecdotal evidence from physicians in China, but these are not peer-reviewed. An ongoing trial in China using Vitamin C (which will conclude on September 30th, 2020) could provide insights.


Melatonin and COVID-19

Melatonin is a hormone that activates the immune system when needed and reduces inflammation. As a result, it has been proven to be helpful in a variety of respiratory and inflammatory diseases. And while there is no direct evidence that it can be used to treat COVID-19, it is possible that it may play a beneficial role. 

Melatonin is also commonly taken to improve sleep, which is a key regulator of the immune system.

Working in the COVID ward

The start was very dramatic, wearing scary-looking hazmat suits. Patients were put on mechanical ventilators, and the emergency room changed overnight.

After a dramatic rise, the number of cases plateaued, and non-COVID-19 related cases are starting to return. Dr. Ku believes, however, that there will most likely be a second wave of COVID-19 in fall and winter.

Regarding his own health, Dr. Ku explains:​“I don't think about my own health that much, because I had already resigned myself to probably getting COVID-19 from the beginning, and that it is a risk that I take.”

“The mental stress is always in the back of our minds,” and he says one of the hardest things is not being able to hug his kids when he gets home. It’s hard for them to understand what is going on. My kids have seen me crying this week.”

‍

Recognizing relevant information on social media

There is a large amount of misinformation circulating. Dr. Ku is learning from trustworthy doctors by following them on Twitter, or listening to their podcasts and blogs.

He feels the FOAM (free open access in medicine) community and Dr. Richard Levitan are trustworthy sources of information.

On the other hand, the U.S healthcare system is fractured as data from electronic health records are siloed. Electronic health records are designed for billing, not for real time decision making. The crisis teaches us that data systems need to be redesigned.

 

Tech helping ease life or death decisions

In early March, it was projected that we would not have enough ventilators, so collaborating with MIT on a bridge ventilator was crucial. New Lab and 10XBeta designed and manufactured a new ventilator in just one month.

Swabs - the little sticks that are put into the patient's nose to test for COVID-19 -, were 3D printed due to severe shortages. The entire lab was repurposed for printing testing swabs.

‍

“We are running out of the most basic medications”

There were not enough meds available to sedate patients to be intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. COVID-19 has completely overwhelmed the supply chains in a matter of weeks.

Hospitals were not designed for pandemics, and some are closing down and laying off healthcare workers. Still, some data shows a 40-50% decline in emergency room visits, possibly because people may be afraid to go to the hospital. Not all hospitals are overloaded like those in New York City, however, and most are safe and can accommodate patients. Dr. Ku fears collateral damage from COVID-19 may be worse than the virus itself.

‍

Telemedicine is here to stay

Telemedicine will become a backbone of the healthcare delivery system, and will play a major role in redesigning this system. It will also help protect the underprivileged: the virus has killed many people with unstable housing, in factory jobs, and in the prison systems.

There needs to be a federal, national unified strategy for the U.S. healthcare system, and this crisis is an opportunity to fundamentally redesign this system.

We are never going back to the old normal.

Connecting to colleagues is important during these times

300 ER doctors joined a Zoom memorial service for one of their colleagues, who worked in NYC and commited suicide during the COVID-19 pandemic. Dr. Ku also learned that two of his colleagues mum’s died of COVID-19.

“I am fortunate to have a job where I can go and actually make a difference during this time.” - Dr. Bon Ku

Dr. Rhonda Patrick on The Joe Rogan Expe.Super_Section:
Know your immune system

Many studies have shown that genetics is not a major regulator of immune response, unlike age and environment. Previous exposure to viruses like Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can also play a major role. In younger adults, this exposure enhances immune function but if you're old, it's deleterious as the virus trains your T-cells to respond to CMV only, which causes a weakened immune response to other viruses. Blood types also play a role in immune response to viruses. Type O blood makes type A antibodies, and these people show less frequency of getting COVID-19. Type Os also seem to have lower levels of the Von Willebrand factor that is involved in clotting, which may help protect against COVID-19.


Status of treatment against SARS-CoV-2

15-30% of common cold infections are attributed to coronavirus, so the theory of cross-immunity across viruses gives hope that common cold antibodies may work on COVID-19. Belgian researchers saw that llamas seem to contain antibodies that can neutralize COVID-19 by binding on the spike protein site, however this is a short-lived solution due to problems in mass production. 

On the other hand, antibody dependent enhancement is a big concern.There are multiple virus strains identified within the SARS-CoV-2. Two particularly interesting ones are the mutations in the spike protein region - the aspartate to glycine mutation. Asians (predominantly in China) have a dominant presence of the aspartate form, while the glycine mutant is prominent in Europeans. This mutation is perhaps causing a higher mortality rate in Europe than in Asia.


Are vitamins the body armour you need in this war?

A study from the Philippines showed that for every standard deviation increase in vitamin D level, people were eight times less likely to have a severe form of COVID-19, and 20 times less likely to be critically ill. 70% of the US population is deficient of vitamin D (<30ng/ml), which your body is supposed to automatically make from exposure to UVB radiation in sunlight. But in non-equatorial countries, exposure to it does not occur all year round and the melanin content in skin blocks this radiation, so people with dark skin now living in temperate regions become severely deficient. African-Americans are seen to be 28 times more deficient in vitamin D than Caucasians. Additionally, elderly and obese people are also more likely to be deficient because this vitamin is fat soluble. Vitamin D is very important for respiratory resilience because it causes homeostasis, but doesn't cause side-effects like increasing Ace2 receptors.

In her article on the importance of vitamin C, Dr.Rhonda explains the difference between the oral and IV forms. Ongoing research in China and the US examine if it helps with COVID-19 resilience. Zinc, also important for the immune system, is found mainly in poultry and red meat. That’s why vegetarians are more prone to zinc deficiency, which can damage T-cell function. Flavonoids like quercetin, found in apples, tea and buckwheat, are also important and have been identified to help against SARS-COV-1 due to their senolytic properties.

‍

Relaxation is the key to staying healthy

Many studies have shown that sauna/hot baths mimic cardio-vascular exercise in terms of the effects they have on your body. This practice can also help with sleep and have antidepressant effects on your mind. Infrared saunas have been shown to treat chronic cardiovascular diseases in some cases. Hot baths increase brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) which regulates neuroplasticity in adults.They also increase heat shock proteins in your body which prevent neuro-degenerative diseases. Cold showers/ice baths after saunas release cold shock proteins that are known to regulate moods and focus attention through norepinephrine release.

Sleep is also crucial for immune function. Melatonin and bright light exposure in the early morning work wonders in setting your circadian clock, while using blue-light blocking glasses for looking at screens may help you sleep better. CBD can help relieve anxiety and stress.

Dream Your Way to a Better You with Dani.Super_Section:
What is lucid dreaming?

A lucid dream is when the dreamer is aware that what s/he is experiencing is a dream. In fact, 50% of the population has experienced at least one lucid dream.

Natalie Sherer is a concert pianist who often has lucid dreams. She wanted to learn more about them so she contacted the Every Little Thing podcast team to ask if they could help her satisfy her curiosity. 


How to induce lucid dreams

Flora Lichtman consulted Professor Daniel Erlacher, who has been studying lucid dreams for decades now, to shed more light on this topic. A lot is still unknown about lucid dreams, but after decades of research, Daniel has found a reliable way to induce them. 

  1. Set your alarm to wake you up in 6 hours.
  2. When the alarm goes off, stay up for an hour.
  3. Whilst awake, reflect on the dream you just had and pick out a detail that seems particularly “dreamlike”, or unrealistic. For example, a flying cow. This detail will serve as a marker to help you identify if you are dreaming. 
  4. After an hour, return to sleep and look for the marker. There is a high chance you will start lucid dreaming.

Professor Erlacher tested this method in a lab and found that every second participant had a lucid dream. 


Can lucid dreams help you in real life?

As a concert pianist, Natalie is familiar with the use of “mental rehearsal” of motor skills as a common technique among musicians. This is when a person imagines themselves performing an activity rather than physically performing it. There is strong evidence that mental rehearsal can greatly improve an individual’s performance. This is because during mental rehearsal, the brain is still producing the same commands as it would during a physical rehearsal. The only difference is that it is not sending the commands to the muscles.

Based on this evidence, Professor Erlacher has formulated a theory that practicing a motor or sport skill during a lucid dream can improve your performance of the skill in real life. To test it, he conducted a pilot study where participants were asked to practice a simple motor task in their lucid dreams. For example, tossing a ten-cent coin into a cup. Participants who were able to practice their assigned task in their lucid dreams showed an improvement in their real-world performance. Professor Erlacher has also gathered anecdotal evidence from athletes in favor of this theory.

Lucid dream therapy is also being used to help people who suffer from recurring nightmares.

What makes a great membership?

Stu McLaren breaks down the key parameters that determine a great membership:

  2. Can you teach a new skill?

Course vs membership

The first thing you need to know is that it is not an either-or relationship between courses and membership. If you teach people a course, you still need membership to help them implement what they’ve learned. There are two kinds of membership types - front-end membership and back-end membership.   2. Cast the vision - and observe the responses you get.
  3. Invite others to join as a founding member - lock prices for founding members and let them have an active say.
  4. Call to action - ask for a vote on going ahead.

Dom’s journey with ketones

Dom’s first introduction to ketones was when he started his US Navy-funded post-doc studying oxygen toxicity seizures. His aim was to develop tech to understand how navy seals could perform physically in extreme deep-sea conditions. In his study, Jong Rho talked about exogenous ketone potential and the therapeutic applications of ketone, which inspired Dom to look into its application in seizures.

At that time, the DARPA was also funding research into the nutritional benefits of ketones, which gave Dom the access to these compounds. Dom discovered that elevating blood ketone provides metabolic resilience and prevents seizures in extreme environments. It actually works better than drugs and has no side effects. A ketogenic diet is a high-fat low-carb diet that has been shown to reduce/prevent a majority of seizure types and help treat epilepsy.


The inner workings of ketones

Dom emphasises the fact that individual ketone levels matter, and not all ketones/ ketone products are the same. It has been observed that when you mix ketogenic fats with salts and esters, a more enhanced response is observed as compared to consuming either alone. There are dozens of potential mechanisms behind a ketogenic diet and its neurological effects, but Dom explains the top four:

  1. A ketogenic diet has been shown to enhance your brain energy metabolism, and balance your energy and glucose metabolism (homeostasis)
  2. A ketogenic diet can completely relax your brain by activating an enzyme that converts glutamate (a hyper-activity enzyme) to GABA, an inhibitory brain stabilizing neurotransmitter. These findings have also led to research on other neurological disorders. 
  3. This diet activates the adenosine 1 receptor, which quiets and stabilizes neurotransmission in your brain.
  4. Ketone bodies have anti-inflammatory properties which reduce neuro-inflammation triggered by foods, stress, environmental toxins, etc. Such events of neuro-inflammation can lead to seizures, anxiety, and headaches.


New modifications to ketogenic diets

New evidence is indicating that a modified and more relaxed ketogenic diet is more beneficial than a conservative one in terms of compliance and efficacy. The classic ketogenic diet for treating seizures contains 4x as much fat as protein and carbohydrates combined, that is, a 4:1 ratio. As the exact ideal ratio is unknown, it seems like you can incorporate fats that are ketogenic into a diet with a higher protein ratio and get the same level of ketosis. In a recent study, it was shown that children with epilepsy on a protein-liberal modified ketogenic diet did better than when they were put on a restrictive ketogenic diet.


Anti-catabolic effects of ketones

Many studies have indicated that ketones protect muscle mass in the body from being broken down. In times of fasting (approx. 1 week), when your blood glucose levels are low, your body starts to breakdown protein and fatty acid for fuel. The depletion of glycogen stores triggers the production of more ketone bodies to replace glucose as a primary energy source. This mechanism is very relevant in the context of calorie restriction or cancer cachexia (muscle wasting in cancer). Ketones supply an energy source which allows your body to spare amino acids thereby maintaining lean body mass.

After dropping out of college, dreaming up a long list of good ideas, and receiving dozens of rejections, Wences met Linda (whom he thought was part of a religious cult). Buying Bitcoin from “Gandalf” to save the legendary road trip

After Wences had to cancel his yearly road trip across continents because his tour bus broke down, he tried to send money from California back home to Argentina to fix it. This proved impossible - until his friend introduced him to Bitcoin, a completely new concept for him in 2011. Even though he was skeptical, he bought $2000 worth of Bitcoin from a Gandalf look-alike in Palo Alto, certain he’d been scammed. But a miracle happened: he was able to send Bitcoins home, save the tour bus, and his road trip. This is when Wences first sensed the revolution of cryptocurrencies. 

 

Hiring hackers to break Bitcoin

Wences hired hackers to see if they could crack the Bitcoin code but Bitcoins’ decentralisation makes it super secure. After the hackers themselves asked to be paid in Bitcoin, there was no turning back for Wences.

“I said, you know what, I want to dedicate the rest of my career, my reputation, and my capital to help this system succeed.”

 

Why growing up in Argentina was important for Wences to succeed

The US dollar is a stable currency and people think little about changing it. In Argentina, however, the government and currency are not as stable or reliable, and might one day just disappear. Wences knew Bitcoin was not an alternative but a revolution for Argentina.

 

Building underground vaults to secure XAPO

Wences founded XAPO with Frederico Murrone to make Bitcoin more trustworthy. People started bringing Bitcoin to the two founders while the price was increasing rapidly.

Wences built underground vaults protected by armed guards to set up secure computer servers, and thus the Fort Knox of Bitcoin was created, reassuring people about the safety of their Bitcoin wallets.

The Bitcoin Revolution of 2014

Mt. Gox, the largest Bitcoin Exchange at the time, went bankrupt. This was a big setback as well as an awakening for crypto security. Bitcoin now sees more than 400,000 transactions per day in XAPO.

Talking to people about M-pesa gave Wences insight on what people actually value about such alternative payment methods.

‍

Wences envisions measuring the value of currencies with the value of Bitcoins in the future.

Establishing a global non-political value for money could break the monetary system free by creating a standard of value that cannot be devalued or censored.

This was an Ask Me Anything (AMA) episode where 50 questions from our followers were chosen. These are the common themes that kept coming up.

How does Hustle Fund operate?

Since they’re a small fund that writes cheques of $25,000, they only invest in software. They don’t invest in physical brands because these require a lot of capital, which doesn’t align with their fund.

Hustle Fund tries to go in very early and make quick decisions. 50% of the time they are the very first VC to check in or be in the first round. Once they get to the call stage, they usually make a decision within 48 hours.

The companies that they invest in must be able to monetize right away. Business models that match this are B2Bs like SAAS, and annual contracts because their margins are great.

Hustle Fund does not invest in companies in the ideas stage. They want to see something built. Yin’s top founder persona is someone that is frugal, scrappy, and a high velocity executor.

What are the benefits of getting funding from Hustle Fund?

  • Their community of founders is made up of smart, active and engaged people who support each other through advice, connections, and introductions.
  • Besides the cheque, they will help you with introductions, and in some cases have done up to 30 introductions.
  • They will help you hone your pitch deck and outbound emails.
  • They carry out workshops for all their founders continuously throughout the year.

 

How to get investment for your start-up

 Cold email, and make sure it’s not a blanket email. 

  • Introductions: find the best company that your target angel investor has invested in. Get someone from that company on your side, and have them introduce you to their angel investor.
  • Do both simultaneously.
  • Pitch by applying directly on their website.

As long as they show that they’re not going to be a pain by calling all the time, and that they have additional value to offer such as fast decision-making skills and the ability to help with the pitch deck, then people will want to take them up. Angel investors can send a cold email to elizabeth@hustlefund.vc.  

 

What is the most important feature that you look for in start-ups?

Customer acquisition, customer acquisition, customer acquisition. They are less interested in traction and more focused on customer acquisition.

The start-up has to be able to show that there is a big problem, and that customers are making it a priority to find a solution.

The start-up also has to show that the solution is profitable. You may have high revenue but the cost to attract and acquire a customer may be high, meaning the margins are low. Hustle Fund wants to know how hard or easy it will be to get the customers, the market pull, and the length and speed of a sale cycle.

 

What type of advice can you share with founders who are looking to raise now, knowing we’re in the middle of a global pandemic?

  • Angel investors and micro-investors are still active, and can write cheques over Zoom.
  • Much larger rounds will be challenging to secure.
  • Wait until we are through with this Covid-19 crisis, but you can prepare materials, get intros to line-up meetings now.

Patrick cited a previous guest on his podcast, Bill Gurley, who has famously said that you need to get collected demand to be able to sell in a marketplace. 

Tobi emphasized that Shop doesn’t seek to be a traditional marketplace; it’s a place to discover merchants and new brands to follow, based on whoever consumers have already purchased products from.


Company processes have to go

Tobi said it’s important for employees to focus their brainpower on the task at hand, instead of following workplace rules by the book.

Changing employees’ behaviour should be done by making it easier for them to do so. One example Tobi shared was when Shopify wanted their employees to return lunch trays. This was made easier by having lunch tray racks placed near the lunchroom exits.

“We avoid processes as much as possible.” – Tobi Lutke

Patrick O’Shaughnessy read the book The Systems Bible by John Gall, and learned that a company is better off with fewer systems in place. Rather, it’s good to trust employees to do the right thing.


Communication and personality are key

Tobi pointed out that Shopify makes communication with employees a priority. He does this with an internal corporate podcast, which he rolls out weekly. In each podcast, Tobi shares the internal decisions being made, and their results.

Tobi believes that personality testing does play a productive role within a company, but feels that it is misused in other companies. 

The primary - and most important - takeaway from personality testing is that people are different. Each person has a different point of view of the world around them.


Video games are good for us!

Patrick remarked in the podcast that, growing up, he played a lot of Starcraft and Warcraft, and other real-time strategy games. He asked Tobi what these games can teach us about real life, including business.

In response, Tobi said that “it feels impossible to say that spending a lot of time in your formative years with something doesn’t somehow shape you in your future.”

The same skills used in a game - playing one race and interacting with others and handling an in-game economy - can be used in running a business, where you transfer talent from one area to another, and make strategic decisions.

To learn more about this philosophy, Tobi recommends the book The Talent Code by Daniel Coyle.

However, the most important takeaway from playing real-time strategy games is whether or not the player is able to pay enough attention to manage everything.

Stoicism and us

Tobi enjoyed reading A Guide to the Good Life by William B. Irvine, a book about the philosophy of stoicism. 

Rather than focus on religion, the book provides a focus on living a good life. The key point that the book makes is to focus on influencing things that are under your control, including yourself.

As an example, Tobi said you don’t have to feel insulted by something another person says about you. In order to be offended, you’d have to accept the insult.

Life Lessons from a Lion Tracker and How.Super_Section:
Challenges lead to healing

Boyd Varty grew up in South Africa, where his father and uncle were lion hunters. They restored a bare plot of land and turned it into a grassland where people could go on safaris. This inspired Boyd’s philosophy about how people are like land.

‍“Land that is traumatized cannot absorb the rainfall, just like a person who’s become traumatized in some way starts to be unavailable to what they actually need.” - Boyd Varty

The Varty Family was pummeled with lawsuits after the land was restored; this went on for ten years. To top it all off, Boyd was attacked by a crocodile and assaulted at gunpoint. At that time, he started to lose his faith in life, until he met a woman who helped him heal and get back on his feet. Boyd has learned that you can heal yourself by finding what you’re passionate about and sharing it with everyone else.

‍
Develop track awareness

Boyd says tracking is like life: you won’t always know where to go, but you can get clues and make an educated guess on what to do. You have to teach yourself to see all the information there is, whether you’re tracking animals or pursuing some other passion.

“Slowly you have to teach yourself to see your track. You have to start tuning into something very specific to you and no one can tell you what your track will be, that is just going to come out of attention.” - Boyd Varty

Boyd encourages developing “track awareness" that is, noticing the things you are curious about and that make you forget about time. Pursuing our big vision takes several tiny steps. Sometimes, we have to determine what’s the next small step we can take that brings us closer to where we want to go. And sometimes, we get lost.
Getting back on track involves self reflection and trying new things. What were you doing last time you felt like you were on the right track? What different things can you do that can help you get back on track? What should you avoid doing, in order to stay on track? Tracking encourages us to step outside of our comfort zone, yet be more realistic about our goals.


Tracking teaches us about body language

Of all people, Boyd knows that lions can be very dangerous, and should be approached with caution. They can be most dangerous when they are defending cubs or eating.

Lions use their body language to communicate their hostility to anyone who comes too close to them; stood up, hunched over, teeth snarled, tail lashing. Boyd says you can fend off an angry lion’s charge by standing your ground and shouting at it; there is a 99% chance of the lion stopping and running away.

“You have to let that lion know, with absolute certainty, that you are dangerous. [...] It teaches you how to communicate without words.“ - Boyd Varty

The same can be said about human body language. Someone’s eyes, posture, and tone of voice can tell us a lot about how they feel. “We can sit down and we can talk, but the real conversation that’s happening between us is the feeling between us.”  Boyd notes that it can be easier for people who have had traumatic childhoods to track animals because they have become more naturally capable of reading into certain cues that signal incoming danger.


Early mortality checks are “initiations”

“I look at all of the things that happened to me [in the past] as initiations.” - Boyd Varty

Boyd recalled the incident where he was tied up and threatened at gunpoint and another time when he got bitten by a crocodile. Such an early check on mortality can increase your desire to love others; and that's exactly what it did for them. As we heal ourselves, we become more connected to nature and learn to prioritize giving over taking.

“The restoration of the planet will come out of a shift in human consciousness” - Boyd Varty

Making and Losing Millions Over and Over.Super_Section:
From rags to riches, then rags again

In the 1990s, James Altucher founded Reset, a web design company that designed websites for the entertainment industry. After a few years, he sold Reset for $15 million. He started a venture capital firm in 1999 and raised $200 million. He also eventually bought himself an apartment in New York City, made various investments and bought stocks.

“I just didn’t know what I was doing.” - James Altucher

Altucher claims that he was losing $1 million per week in 2000 because he did not understand risk or money management. By mid-2001, he went to zero and desperately tried to sell his apartment - when the World Trade Center was attacked and the stock market became more volatile as a result.

There are other times when Altucher made millions and lost everything again. He recalls building a social media website, which he describes as “MySpace of finance,” and later selling it for $10 million.

“And then a year later, I was broke again. [...] Things like that just kept happening.”


Teaching yourself about investing

“I had to teach myself how to invest, so I wrote some software where I took every piece of data about every single stock since WWII and looked for patterns. I would have my software find statistically significant patterns where trades were good. So I would try to model, say, fear and greed in the markets, and it worked pretty well.” - James Altucher

This strategy worked because there weren’t as many quantitative investors in the market at that time. This gave Altucher time to learn about investing and talk to expert investors.

“I am the worst idiot in the world. [...] What I mean by that is, I didn’t have to do any work once I invested because Peter Thiel was an investor.” - James Altucher


The science behind the sale

Altucher pointed out that selling a company requires skills: first with starting a company, then building it and selling it.

Part of the experience involves meeting people, then there is what Altucher describes as a “courtship.” Then, when the relationship kicks into full gear, there is a “due diligence” period when the selling comes next. It is also important to be able to get along with your employees.

“You have to have a vision that matches their vision very strongly and it has to explain [...] if your business is so great, why would you want to sell it?” - James Altucher

Negotiation skills are an absolute must. With multiple formulas used for valuing a company, it’s crucial to understand the variables of a formula enough when negotiating with potential buyers.


The importance of self-care

Every single time he lost everything, Altucher faced depression and was suicidal. Over time, this taught him that it’s important to maintain good physical, emotional, spiritual and creative health.

  • Physical health: Are you getting enough to eat? Enough sleep? Enough fresh air?
  • Emotional health: Are you surrounding yourself with good people?
  • Spiritual health: Are you trying to control stuff out of your control?
  • Creative health: Are you a fountain of new ideas?


The idea writing process

Altucher has developed a routine of formulating and writing down ten ideas to himself every day, which has rewired his brain to be more creative and pitch good ideas to other companies.

He’s come up with a process called “idea sex,” where you take ideas from two different industries and combine them into an “idea baby” that could work. As an example, Altucher talks about monetizing a good meal at a restaurant as well as the good behaviour of a waitress. With servers being at the bottom third of the food industry, how can that bottom third be lightened up to make more money?

Finally, some key advice Altucher has for making money is to enter the marketplace with a unique perspective, and offer content that is worth paying for.

“When I write something, I don’t hit ‘Publish’ unless I’m afraid of what people will think about me after I hit ‘Publish,’ because otherwise then I’m probably not saying something new or different. [...] I have to challenge myself in some way to create new content.”

COVID-19 and the US economy

The mismanagement of the COVID-19 pandemic response has led to over 30 million people being unemployed. Chamath Palihapitiya points out that many currently unemployed people will probably choose to not return to the workforce after the lockdown lifts.

  • “How many of the people that are leaving the workforce may never come back? That has a societal toll and a weight that we will all have to bear.” - Chamath Palihapitiya

David Sacks estimates that it will take roughly two or three years for the economy to recover, unless another proportionally-large unforeseen crisis arises. It is misleading to look at the technology and software companies who are doing well in this pandemic and draw the conclusion that the economy is in recovery. The economy is, in fact, doing terribly despite government measures to keep it afloat.

Jason Calacanis predicts that if remote work was to continue after the lockdown is lifted, companies would be able to reach never-before-seen levels of efficiency and profitability. Working remotely allows managers to work closely with their teams, and replace the “bottom people” with talent and skills from anywhere in the world. Additionally, companies would no longer pay for large office spaces or fees to relocate their employees. Working remotely cuts out office politics and busywork, and frees up employees’ time, which would lead to positive impacts personally, professionally, and socially.


Mass migration is likely imminent

Cities like San Francisco rely on the network effects caused by Silicon Valley; i.e. if you want to be considered for a tech job position in a big player company, you would have to live and know people in San Francisco. If remote work persists, employees will be able to live wherever they want. And since big cities like San Francisco have such high tax rates and costs of living, those employees would likely move elsewhere.

Furthermore, if the COVID-19 spread persists, high-risk populations (older people, those who are immunocompromised, etc.) will likely also choose to move away from cities. 


Politicization of the way forward

Chamath is frustrated that even though dealing with the pandemic should have been relatively straightforward, it has been transformed into a Left vs. Right issue, which is now culminating in mask-wearers trying to prolong the lockdown while those who are anti-masks are pushing to end it. 

“There just doesn’t seem to be enough political wherewithal and courage to… do the right thing, independent of what your political persuasion is.” - Chamath Palihapitiya

Sacks believes the “right thing” would involve safely reopening the country under proper health and safety requirements, like wearing masks, social distancing, etc. However, with governors unable to get on the same page, that possibility seems unlikely right now. Furthermore, the unwillingness to end the lockdown may overshadow the discussion around the incompetent response to the pandemic, and could very well lead to Trump’s re-election come November 2020. 

The lack of accurate and reliable knowledge regarding the effectiveness of hydroxychloroquine against the SARS-Cov-2 virus leaves a lot of room for debate and politicization.

"When there’s a lot of room for debate, you usually revert to some kind of base belief or base political point of view.” - David Friedberg


The modern Cold War: US vs. China

Due to numerous strategic investments over the last few decades, China has come close to usurping the United States’ position as a world leader.

“China is a much more worthy adversary for [the USA] than the USSR was at their peak.” - Chamath Palihapitiya

Trade creates wealth, but it also creates interdependence. So although it would be impractical to completely cut off ties with China, the US should not be dependent on it for essential equipment for survival, such as PPE and ventilators. David Sacks is concerned that the decoupling from China will also become a bi-partisan issue, when the real focus should be on establishing a better trade balance and reciprocity.

Friedberg predicts that unless the US decides to revolutionize the production process, there is simply no way to replace China as a manufacturer without the cost of everything going up five-fold. However, if the US were to reinvent production, it could go on to replace China as the world manufacturer.

COVID-19 as a changemaker

The world has stood still because of the global pandemic, causing lasting changes on the economy. Naval Ravikant points out how we are collectively adapting to this rapid shift: ordering everything online, working from home, and some even losing their livelihood and having to reinvent themselves.

New Zealand is slowly becoming one of the most attractive green zones because of how it has handled the pandemic, with no new recorded cases as of the time of this writing. Naval highlights the significant factors that may have contributed to New Zealand’s success – its geography and the fact that the majority of its workforce are remote workers. 

‍

The rise of digital 

The lockdown imposed in every part of the globe has drastically affected the economy, and it cannot stay this way because of the possibility of economic collapse. This is why Naval urges businesses to make the shift to digital. Industries like tourism and infrastructures are most likely to suffer. He shares how the new normal is turning our lifestyle “from gray to green” – from urban to nature, and how it also shapes the new needs of the market. As a result, companies offering digital goods are doing great despite difficult times.

‍

A collective test 

Naval believes this a collective test – a single problem to be solved collectively. He demonstrates the need for the government and private sector to work together for the economy to survive this pandemic, which may go on for years. 

Entrepreneurs are the most affected and need the most assistance, now more than ever. Naval shares a strategy the government can adopt – partnering with organizations like Edmund Hillary Fellowship (EHF) in implementing immigration programs that will strengthen the country’s workforce and create a new hot spot for tech start-ups just like Silicon Valley. According to Naval, companies should train workers to be digitally literate and incentives must be given to those who undergo training. For countries like New Zealand, he suggests finding the best and the brightest from different parts of the world and issuing work visas for them. He also recommends bringing in investors with the highest qualifications and urging them to fund the digital literacy programs for students. 

‍

How investors can help rebuild the economy

Now that people are using a lot more technology from their homes, more people are seeing value in them and are therefore investing in tech. Being forced to work remotely has given investors more access to talents. 

For investors, Naval suggests investing in one great cause instead of little investments – one that is economy-focused and can bring in passionate changemakers. Start-ups should have a local-driven collaborator that can provide knowledge and resources for them too. 

‍

Advice for start-ups 

Podcast host Yoseph presents the challenge founders are facing today – not having the smart capital for rapid growth. Naval proposes the solution of training their talents to become more digitally literate, which can attract more investors. Accelerating the shift to digital economy is the way. 

“Investors follow the talent. If you can pull in the talent, the money will follow.” - Naval Ravikant 

For start-ups, he thinks now is the perfect time to take a leap of faith. If they see great potential, venture capitalists will want to invest in your company before it even launches. Now that everything is done online, remote investing has become the norm, which means more possibilities awaiting your business. 

For businesses needing a global market, Nadal recommends riding the wave of digital export. “Think of anything digital that you can scale globally,” he adds. He also suggests investing in cryptocurrency, comparing it to the struggle of every immigrant who takes the same risk when they start over in a different country. 

This is the time to take as much risk as you can to increase market share, recruit the best talent, invest in digital products, and acquire customers who are eager to try anything new from their homes. According to Naval, there is no such thing as being lucky, so we should all just make luck work for us.

Fear and anxiety

While fear is a necessary part of life and survival, it should not consume us. “Fear is a gift… but it becomes a curse the moment you can’t let go of it.” - Sam Harris

  • The COVID-19 pandemic is not the time for inexperienced/new substance users to start experimenting, especially with hospitals currently being unsafe places to visit.

Remember that you can accomplish so much even by just focusing on supporting the people in your life. Whether it is your closest friends or family members, or even someone peripheral — like your hairdresser — do your best to help.

“We should be looking for opportunities to help the people who are more vulnerable than we are.” - Sam Harris

Even the gesture of reaching out to let people know that you are willing to help could act as a huge psychological and emotional boost for them. If you don’t have a framework to follow for your decisions or if you are struggling to find clarity under these stressful circumstances, don’t beat yourself up. Those feelings are not reflective of your personal shortcomings or your own lack of ability. Remember that those same feelings are being collectively experienced by millions of people everywhere.

Focus on the silver lining. This pandemic has shaken up our preconceived notions of the world and how we would like it to be. This is an opportunity to reevaluate our priorities. We must endeavor to maintain the insights we have gained from this pandemic even after life has returned to normal.

“We have to keep an inventory of all the lessons being learned here and do better next time.” - Sam Harris

Why you should read up on Warren Buffet and Charlie Munger

Some business owners never read about their industry (do the opposite!), and reading biographies can help you recognize the mistakes people have made along their business journeys, and how to avoid making these yourself. 

Charlie Munger uses a collection of rules and blueprints for problem solving which he calls “The Latticework of Mental Models.” 

He employs two main strategies:

  1. The availability bias -  a mental shortcut that relies on immediate examples that come to a person's mind when evaluating a specific topic, concept, method, or decision.
  2. Incentive caused bias - the impact of incentives on changing human behavior and cognition, working as conscious and subconscious drivers for decisions.

Invisible scripts and money dials

“We all intuitively know that as you change in life, your spending is gonna change.” – Ramit Sethi.

These beliefs that run our lives are invisible scripts. Dan Kennedy said, “Why pay less when you can pay more?” Most people go through life looking through a frugality lens where everything is about cost.

There is a famous saying: “A fool and his money are soon separated.” There is a limit between the money you spend and the money you have.

Ramit, for one, is highly frugal. “I like having little places in my life where I intentionally impose scarcity. I think it’s healthy to have restraint to build that discipline.” Spend on things you love and cut costs on things you don’t love.

With a money dial, pick the area that you love spending money on, and 10x it. Money should be bifurcated – spending little on the things you do not like and going extravagant on the things you do.

 

Negotiating

“In life you don’t get what you deserve, you get what you negotiate.” – Tim Ferriss.  Sometimes negotiating is just asking for what you want. Do not do it unless you are interested.

 

Save and invest

Save and invest at least 20-30% of your income. Pick a date you are going to retire and invest until then. Your money will double every seven years, and that’s why compounding is so powerful.

 

Prenups

Prenups sets the terms of what you are coming into a marriage with. It is an acknowledgement that certain people might have certain assets or interests, like a business. It also sets the terms for what happens if a marriage ends, and what is to be done with those assets. Negotiate in good faith.

  • If you ever see a book you are even remotely interested in, buy it.
  • Have a year of cash available. If you do not have it, build up to it.
  • Save up for big expenses.
  • If anything looks good at a restaurant, just order it.
  • Have a couple of areas in your life for which you have absolutely no budget.
  • Eat the same thing mostly every single day.
  • Come up with some basic rules within your relationship together. Make a basic guideline so that you don’t have to think about it all the time.

Ramit thinks morning routines are overrated, and Tim disagrees. “Morning routines are one example of removing decisions.” It serves as a “boot up sequence” says Tim. For Tim, on the other hand: “The tools are by-products of principles or strategies.” They approach problem solving differently, but their values and principles are similar.

If it’s not in your calendar, it’s not real. This includes issues in your relationships that need to be discussed, date nights, taking trips together, visiting each other’s families, etc. Tim and his girlfriend make time to discuss what they have been doing well/better, and where they feel they’ve dropped the ball or could focus on more.They take notes of their meeting and forward them to the other person. 

“The ritual itself may be even more important than the content.” – Ramit Sethi.

There are times where they do not have stuff to talk about and push it back a week. But keep it in the calendar and opt-out for that week. Put everything into the calendar – call your parents, read a book, go to the gym.

 “You decide, don’t let the world decide for you.” – Ramit Sethi.

What is a blockchain?

Blockchain is made of different layers:
